intro: Nothaphoebe meyeniana, commonly known as the New Zealand mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Lauraceae family and typically grows on the branches of host trees such as pines and tōtara. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually arranged in whorls around the stem. Its flowers are white or pale green and are followed by small, fleshy berries that are important for bird dispersal. Nothaphoebe meyeniana plays a significant role in the ecological dynamics of its native forests.
